review_blob:
A: Very clear, light amber pour with nearly no head.  

S: Citrus hops and lemon peel dominate the nose while bready pils malts are in the background.  A little bit of hot alcohol as well.

T: Delicious spicy hops are up front with a nice grainy pils backbone.  Nothing overly complex, as you should expect with a beer of this nature.  Youd never guess this is 7.2% by taste.  This is a wonderfully crafted beer.

M:  This has more body than some other impy pils Ive had before (DFH My Antonia comes to mind) but it serves it well.  Medium carbonation doesnt scrub away flavor too quickly and leaves a great taste in your mouth.

O: A fantastic beer with a small cast of flavors that hold hands and get along great together.  Kudos to FFF for another delicious beer.

Bottle in 5 oz snifter sampler.

A: Pours to a brilliantly clear pale straw color with a rapidly growing, but slowly dissipating white head. Excellent lacing.

S: This nose is going to be hard to beat. A great blend of bready pils malt, earthy and citrus hops, and a nice dose of alcohol heat.

T: Very interesting, in a good way. Dry as a pils should be, but with a bit more meat on its bones. Hop flavors steal the show on this one. Its a nice mixture of citrus and spice. The only thing Im not a big fan of is the alcohol hotness, but I guess its unavoidable with an imperial pils.

M: Between the dry finish and upfront hop bite, I can only describe this one as "crisp."

O: Very tasty beer, albeit a bit hot for me. If I had tasted this before I bought, I might reconsider the $12 purchase. Still glad Ive tried it.

Bourbon Barrel 2010 on tap at the FFF pub after DLD.

A: Thick and black. You could use it to lube up an old engine. Slowly dissipating, tan head. Legs like a supermodel.

S: Nice balance of bourbon, malt sweetness and a little coffee hiding in the background.

T: Wonderful balance of all things awesome. Bourbon most certainly played a supporting role in this one. Far less angular that non-BBA 2010, it doesnt have the eccentric bitter bite that its little brother has. Nice boozy warmth and plenty of fig, coffee and toffee. Delicious.

M: Thick enough to brush your teeth with. Very low carbonation. The time in the barrel and this being a year old now make it nice and smooth.

O: Im very impressed with this one. I was lucky enough to be at the brew pub right when they opened the day after DLD. It allowed me to really dissect this one without the craziness of the previous days festivities surrounding me.

If youre ever in a situation in which you can try this guy out, take advantage of it. This was magical beer.
beer_name: Three Floyds Dark Lord Russian Imperial Stout (Bourbon Barrel Aged)

review_blob:
Bottle.  Pours to a super hazy rusty orange with a creamy, everlasting beige head.  Nose is mostly malt sweetness, with little to no hop aroma - this isnt exactly what I expected from a IIPA.  After swishing it around a bit I can pull what I think is a little piney hop nose, but still not much.  Very full bodied with tons of American hops.  Pretty bitter,  tastes like a 70/30 pine/citrus hop ratio.    Very warming going down.  Its sweet, but not too sweet.  Slightly dryer than DFH 90 Minute.

Maybe Im getting burned out on I/IPAs, but this one didnt do too much for me.  Its good beer, but is still too sweet for me.

Can from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours to a very clear (when held to a light) very dark red-brown.  Head forms and dissipates quickly.  Nose is all carmel malts, fig, and dried fruits.  Flavor is very robust and complex with sweet (but not too sweet) malts providing a flavor profile similar to the nose.  A very good Scotch ale, but not something Id be able to drink often.

Bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours to a very clear red-brown with a creamy, light tan head.  Light, sweet nose of roasted malts and toffee.  Medium-light bodied with a slightly hop-heavy balance of roasted grains and earthy hops.  A very noticeable metallic finish makes it hard to give this a good rating for flavor.  It would be fantastic with a little less tin.  As with other Duck-Rabbit beers Ive had, I think the carbonation level is a little high, but not overbearingly.  I will not be buying this again until they get rid of that metallic flavor.  This is the first of their beers I havent been wild about.

Bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  A nearly pitch black pour, hints of reddish brown come through the edge of the glass when held to a light.  Minimal, fast tan head.  Nose is coffee beans and dark chocolate with a hint of sweet toffee in the back.  Beautiful.  This beer tastes great - very flavorful while remaining non-abrasive in any aspect.  It starts off with a bit of piney flavor but mostly a great grain-founded bitterness that is well met with a smooth texture from the lactose.  It finishes with a perfect blend of sweet and roast.  This is very well made stout.  Buy this beer.

Can from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours to a very hazy rusty orange with a quickly dissipating one finger, beige head,  Nose is buttery toffee.  Weird.  While ESB is one of my favorite styles of beer, I cant say that Im looking forward to drinking this after that smell - there isnt even a hint of hop presence.  The hop selection is too citrusy for this style and malt profile.  It starts out with a nice bitterness, but finishes too dry for an ESB and has a very watery feel to it.  This beer is a mess.  From the bizarre nose to downright poor ingredient selection, I would honestly drink BMC over this.  It reminds me of my first homebrew.  I would not recommend this to a friend.

12 bottle as a gift from a friend in Philly.  The light burnt out in my office room, so I have to judge this beers appearance from the glow of my monitor.  Fuck yeah.  Pours to a Miller Lite yellow with a one finger white head.  Crystal clear.  A small, spicy hop aroma and lightly toasted malts.  Its like smelling a great ESB from a foot away - the aromas are just barely there.  I think this beer is excellent for its style.  Its got a beautiful bready malt character balanced by a crisp hop bite.  Its medium-light bodied and perfect for a hot sumer day (Im typing this naked in a non-air conditioned midwstern house.)  Ill be sure to pick some up when I visit my friends in Philly.

12 oz can from some mom and pop gas station in NC.  Pours to a beautiful amber with a one finger, fluffy white head.  Nose is grassy, floral and maybe  a HINT of citrus hops.  This is a nice, dry APA with a great lingering bitterness.  Its rare that Ive been able to taste malts and hops so seperatly in a pale ale before.  This beer lets the hops do everything they need to without bothering the malts flavors - great job!  There is a very clean, non aggressive bitterness, followed by a bit of a citrus blast and a dry finish from the hops.  Id be damned if there wasnt a little bit of British pale malt, and fair amount of crystal malts in this beer.  Very, very tasty beer.

Bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours to a very dark brown with a quickly dissipating tan head.  Nose is all malt, very roasty and caramel.  Tastes like dark chocolate, caramel and coffee.  Better than I was expecting after reading some of the other reviews on here.  Medium-full bodied with a medium-quick finish.  Very tasty,

Bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills.  Pours to a clear amber with a thin, white head.  Nose is light strawberry and sugar.  Flavor tastes like a strawberry dum-dum sucker with a very mild malt background.  If youre looking for a BEER, you wont like this.  However, if youre looking for an interesting strawberry flavored drink - this stuff it quite good.

Can from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Can pops open without any fizz sound, I can smell the hops as a pour it into my glass.  Pours to a rusty copper with a thin, white head.  Nose is moderately strong floral and fruity hops with sweet malts in the background.  The head has sank into nothing but a small white film.  This is a very clean tasting IPA with little yeast character and a perfect bitterness.  Hop flavors are a nice mix of mostly citrus and a little pine.  Carmel malts balance this out very nicely while still being very hop-forward (but un-abrasive.)  It has a nice, dry finish with a nice lingering bitterness.  This is an excellent IPA.  If I get the chance, I will be a returning customer.

12 oz. bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours to a fizzy, blood red with a minimal - but lingering tan head.  Beautiful.  Nose is caramel sweet and toasted malts with a small amount of burnt character.  FUCKING GIRLFRIEND JUST SCARED THE SHIT OUT OF ME.


All better.


This lager drinks like an ale with a highly malty body full of complexities.  Caramel is the most obvious flavor, while prunes and other dried fruits hide in the back.  I usually find these flavors to be overbearing, but this beer is very well balanced.  Hops do their job of balance and nothing more.  This is a very finely crafted dunkel, I hope these beers find their way to Ohio soon!

Bottle from Summer variety pack.  Pours to a red-orange with a one finger, rocky head.  Nose is lighter than your average IPA, but grapefruit citrus notes prevail, while slightly sweet malts take the sidelines.  The first sip provides a nice clean bitterness and a mouthful of citrus hops.  Im getting a bit of lemon and grapefruit that are complimented by a balance of crystal malts.  Gorgeous lacing.  This is a well balanced, while remaining hop heavy IPA.  It is by no means a hop bomb or anything that should be highly sought after, but if it was sold in 6-packs, Id buy it regularly.  Sammy boy delivers another solid drink.

Bottle, pours to a hazy orange with a loose, white head.  Nose is a decent blast of piney hops.  The taste is big.  A nice, harsh bitterness with an evident alcohol burn.  My tongue feels like a punching bag, this is one of the more aggressively hopped IIPAs Ive had in a while.  Very piney flavors all around, its like drinking a fucking camping trip.  Nice, tight lacing on the glass.  It has an extremely resinous mouth feel, and I may be getting some sweetness from the malt, but the hop profile is so pronounced its hard to tell.  Dont expect one of those sissy lil balanced IIPAs.  This monster is a hop bomb, good and proper.
beer_name: Great Lakes Lake Erie Monster Imperial IPA

review_blob: Bottle shared with my broad.  Pours to a very slightly hazy, reddish-copper with a quickly dissipating cream head.  The nose is very funky, nearly astringent.  Very exciting.  This is fantastically sour.  The zinfandel flavors compliment the soured fruits and brett very well. High carbonation provides a quick, dry finish.  I need to go buy some more bottles!

Bottle from a variety pack.  Pours to a very clear amber with a rocky cream head.  Nose is piney hop resin, very pleasant.  It has a very crisp bitterness and a very full, crystal malty profile.  I may be tasting some fruity esters?  This is a very good every-day IPA.

After drain-pouring the barleaywine from this year;s LongShot, Im moving onto Old Ben Ale.  Pours to a bold copper with a small, quickly dissipating beige head.  Nose is malty sweetness with maybe just a hint of roasted grains and dried fruits.  This thing is a malt bomb.  Nice flavor profile of carmel malts, nut, and raisin.  It finishes sweet, but not too sweet.  The hops here are doing their job and nothing more - good.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot Old Ben Ale

review_blob:
Pours to a clear, rusty copper with a thin, beige head.  Nose is a mix of caramel sweetness, dark fruits, and citrus hops - interesting.  For a barleywine, this thing is pretty hoppy.  Starts kind of abrasive in that regard, but finishes sweet with fig notes.  Even without the hops getting in the way, I think this is a little two-dimensional for a barleywine.  It finishes pretty sweet with caramel and fig flavors, and an all-too-present hop profile for my liking.  Provides a nice alcohol warmth.

This is a bigger beer, so I will give it the benefit of a doubt and age my other bottle and re-rate later.  In my opinion, the extra hops muddy this beer instead of making it something special.  Hopefully time will make me think otherwise.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot Mile High Barleywine

review_blob: Pours to a brilliantly clear light amber with a bright white head.  Foam remains constant due to high carbonation levels.  Nose is zesty with a strong yeast character, maybe a little funky.  Hops provide just enough bitterness, but let the spices and zest take the spotlight on flavor.  It has a nice bite to it, but far from being overbearing.  While I may not be very proficient in the saison style, the others that Ive tasted before had a much fruiter ester profile than this one.  This is very easy drinking.  "Lacing" doesnt to this beer justice, foam covers the glass like wallpaper.  I think Ill save my other bottle for a brutal summer day.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot Lemon Pepper Saison

review_blob:
Can from a DLD trade.  Thanks, random person!

Pours to a nice amber with a perfect white head.  Nose is very strong, and full of citrus and piney hops.  The taste is a medley of hop perfection.  Very fruity, like a succulent mango,  robust with flavor but not as bitter as the name "Abrasive" would imply.  I imagine the folks at Surly loaded up the late hop and dry hop additions to achieve this hop-heads dream beer.  This isnt the driest of the style, but I think the lingering sweetness adds something special to its flavor profile.

This is damn fine beer.  If this was available in Ohio, Id be a regular customer.

Bottle from Speedway :P

Since its bottle conditioned, I poured it like a homebrew - leaving the last 1/4 inch unserved.  Crystal clear golden color with a nice, thick white head.  Nose is bight, citrus hops.  Dry as a pale ale should be with a crisp finish with a fantastic citrus character.  This one is available everywhere and should be enjoyed by many.

2004 vintage in a 8.5oz bottle.  This beer has been in my fridge for the better part of a year.  I decided to lose myself in Final Fantasy XIII and enjoy a true english barley wine.  I let it warm up in the kitchen for about 20 minutes and popped the lid.  The carbonation level rivals that of the finest trappist ales, resulting in a towering beige head.  Its nose is dark, dried fruits and toffee.  A taste reveals many things: raisin, caramel, and fig.  It has a very thick consistency, thicker than many Imperial Stouts Ive had.

This beer is everything a barley wine should be - complex and mysterious.  In true English fashion, you wont find a hint of hop flavor in this barley wine.

Bomber split with Raninator84.  Pours to a lupalin-induced hazy amber with a thin white head.  The nose on this beer steals the show.  If youve never smelled whole hops right out of the bag, just pour yourself a glass of Hop Dam.  As far as flavor, this beer delivers the whole hop experience, start to finish.  The bittering lasts an eternity, and the immediacy of hop flavors comes quickly.  Hoppin Frog proves once again that they are far more than "the guys that make B.O.R.I.S."
beer_name: Hoppin Frog Hop Dam Triple IPA

review_blob: UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010

At 10.69% ABV and 102 IBUs, this is a beast.  The nose is a blast of citrusy, well rounded hops (Simcoe maybe??) with a pronounced sweetness from its enormous malt backbone.  It pours to a cloudy orange with a quickly dissipating white head. With such a high IBU count, I think I over prepared myself for the hop bitterness.  While is certainly is very bitter, I think its got more flavor from the hops than bite.  The malt profile must be loaded with plenty of carmel and maybe even honey malt, this thing is pretty sweet.  The Maharaja is a shining example of a IIPA, whose subtle complexities will make it my new standard for comparisons amongst the style.
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: 12 oz bottle, thanks to Raninator84!  Rours to a clear, rusty orange with a nice beige head.  Nose is heavy citrus hops and pine.  This thing is hop bomb.  Plenty of flavor additions and enough bittering hops to take the paint off a car.  It has a nice carmely malt backbone that faintly shines through.  If balance is what your looking for, stay clear.  This is the full hop experience.

12 oz bottle from the brewery.  Pours to a fairly opaque brown with a one finger beige head.  Nice lacing.  Nose is roasted malts, carmel and a slight hint of chocolate.  There isnt a hint of hop presence.  The flavor has a huge malt backbone, with just the right amount of carbonation.  Its got a great roasty profile, while remaining fairly sweet.  The hops are doing their job well by preventing cloying sweetness, but going undetected from taste.  Loads of carmel. This is an excellent beer - I will be making the 200+ mile trip to get more soon!
beer_name: Three Floyds Robert The Bruce Scottish Ale

review_blob: Bottle, gifted by a friend.  Pours to a very hazy, nut color brown with a healthy beige head.  Nose is prune, raisin and classic trappist yeasty notes.  This has a beautifully complex flavor profile, but feels slightly masked by too much carbonation.  Dried fruits are at the forefront of this one, while fruity esters provide a backbone.  This is fairly mild bodied for its style and makes it dangerously quaffable.  I should like to drink this one again some day.

What would a rock show be without PBR?  Can, pours to a fizzy yellow with a quickly fading white head.  Nose is nothing with a hint of malt.  Good.  Clear as (slightly yellow tinted) glass.  Tastes is nothing but carbonated malt water thats been run through steel an sand paper.  Sure, this beer isnt anything to write home about, but it has a very special place in my heart.  Cheers to an unflattering brew!

Can pours to a crystal clear light amber with a quickly dissipating, fluffy white head.  Nose is...dish soap?  I drank a beer out of this glass a few minutes ago and didnt smell that.  Well call it 6-row soap malt.  No hop presence in the nose.  It actually has a flavor!  I was expecting a another PBR.  It is very malty sweet with just enough hops to make it work.  This would be a decent stepping stone for BMC drinkers to try something new without scaring them away.  It isnt spectacular by any means, but when the bar is set so low for blue cans, something with more than yellow fizz can be downright shocking.  Cant beat the price, either.  12 cans at $6 aint too shabby.

Pours to a fizzy yellow that were all familiar with.  Head vanishes instantly.  Nose is very light malt, maybe a little skunk, no hops are detectable.  Highly carbonated.  I guess its pretty good for what it is.  Nobody that drinks this is expecting a robust, full flavored beer.  This is a football brew.  Light malt flavor, barely any bitterness.  Crisp, dry finish.

Bottle, courtesy of ditmier.  Pours to a copper-brown with a big boy, heavily lacing head.  If the nose is any indication of the taste, this will be very well balanced between malt sweetness and a good hop bite.  This is a nice American take on a Brittish classic.  Hop presence can be detected throughout with a nice, lingering bitter (almost sour) finish.  The malt profile is well rounded and fits the style to a tee.  If I could get this in Dayton, it would be in regular rotation.

Pours to fairly opaque reddish-brown with a thin, off-white head.  Nose is roasted malts and fig.  I was surprised with the complexity of this one.  Flavor profile includes caramel, toffee, chocolate, and finishes with a slightly bitter roasted coffee note.  Maybe a little thin on the palate, with a non-hop bitter aftertaste from the roasted malts.  St. Peters has never impressed me, but this is a very drinkable, but highly complex beer that I will certainly be buying again.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2009

Thanks to ditmier for hooking it up with this one!  This beer gives a cloudy orange pour (I didnt notice it was bottle conditioned, so it may be a cloud of yeasties I foolishly poured in) with a white head with decent retention.  Nice lacing.  Itr has a very faint nose, mostly a little spicy hops and maybe a bit of clove.  The flavor is not what I would have expected from an American IPA.  A few more bittering hop during the boil wouldnt have killed the folks at Grand Trenton.  The flavor is dominated by spicy hop flavors and a too-light malt backbone. It almost drinks like a wheat.  I will not be pursuing this beer again, but if Im at a bar with only BMC and this to choose from, Ill take a Sweetgrass.

Cask @ Barleys.  Head was everything an impy stout should be - thick, tan and unforgiving.  Nose was super roasty-sweet malts, coffee and a little chocolate.  The flavor profile was the same, but not as complex as I had expected.  The impression on my palate, however, was downright disappointing.  For an imperial, I was expecting much more body out of this.  The flavor was close to a Breakfast Stout, but with the body of a Guinness.  For what its worth - this mixed with their brownie is the most flawless.

Growler from Barleys.  Nice beige head with brilliant lacing and retention in this orange colored beer.  Nose is a fantastic mash of sweet malt and bright, citric hops.  Nice hop flavor from start to end, but never too overpowering.  Very well balanced with a generous amount of sweet, light malts.  Leaves a nice bite your tongue wont soon forget.  This is by no means the best IPA in the world, but the best within a short drive from Dayton!

Tap at Barleys.  Cloudy orange in appearance with a one finger beige head, beautiful lacing.  Nice hop bite with a citrus finish, very well balanced.  Well worth checking out in youre in Columbus - and their food is fantastic.

Might rating might be off, as the bottle is a few years old.  A friend bought a case in Germany a while ago and gave me a couple bottles.  Pours to a cola color with no head (maybe has to do with the age??) Nose is very sweet, a lot of caramel and well rounded malts.  This is an absolutely delicious beer.  The carmel from the aroma is very present in the flavor profile, and gives it an almost creamy mouthfeel.  Not a single hint of hop bitterness.  This is a very enjoyable Dunkel that Id love to have again.

Pours to a clear amber with an orange-khaki head.  Its got a sweet, yeasty nose.  If they cut some water out of the equation, this could be a much better brew.  This wouldnt make for a bad session beer.  Cheers to Trader Joes for trying.

Bottle.  Pours to a very dark red-brown with an instantly forming khaki head.  The Zinfandel is very present on the nose, as is fruity spice and a little oak.  Im mixed about the wine barrel aging.  Part of me feels it clashes rather than assist the beer, but I also feel that with a little getting used to, it might be magical.  Whatever the case, Im glad I tried it, and cheers to Avery for their experimentation.
UPDATED: MAY 2, 2011
beer_name: Three Floyds Dark Lord Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours to a bold orange with a bright white head.  Nose is very floral, bright hops, pine and round malt characters.  Flavor is, again very bright hops from beginning to end, nice citrus bite and good, balancing malts.  Id love to be able to buy this regularly.  Great job!

Bottle.  Pours to a light amber with a quickly dissipating one-finger white head.  Yeast still swimming after the pour.  Nose is light but can still pick away fruits (berry and banana) and some spice.  Classic Belgian flavor, very sweet.
beer_name: AleSmith / Mikkeller / Stone Belgian Style Tripel Ale

review_blob: Bottle (thanks to HOPSHUNTER!)  Pours to a super thick, cloudy hop syrup with a lasting, white head.  Maybe its the fact that I cant buy this in Ohio, but I was very highly impressed with this one.  While it most certainly isnt a session beer (I found it a challenge to champ the whole bottle,) it is truly a work of art.  More of a cider or nectar than I would have thought.  Nose is malt, sweet honey, alcohol and very floral hops.  Its very sugary sweet and thick on the palate.  I would love to have this one again.  Big ups to DFH for making such a ridiculous product.

Bottle,  Pours to a clearish-copper with a one finger, white head.  Nose is malts, banana, nutmeg and the season of Fall.  Really.  Taste is malty pumpkin with a thin spice finish.  This is a fairly watery product for the folks at DFH.  Its worth having a few times, but nothing to hoard.
Everyone else has already said what needs to be said about this near perfect beer.  I cracked one open to welcome the first great day of Spring in Dayton, OH.  What a wonderful world :-)

Pours to an oily black with a thin, tan, slowly dissipating head that beautifully laces (and stains) the glass.  Nose is whiskey and sweet roasted malts.  This is an amazingly balanced beer, there are worlds of flavor - none of which stand in the foreground.  A bit of whiskey, chocolate, coffee, roasted grains, dried fruit, and just enough finishing hops.  I sincerely hope barrel aging Boris becomes standard practice to the fellas at Hoppin Frog.  A job well done!
beer_name: Hoppin Frog Barrel Aged BORIS The Crusher
